sections.title: The Wisdom and Mercy of God

verses.text: He who lives forever created all things together. The Lord alone is righteous.
verses.comment: Here, God’s eternal existence and creative action are emphasized. Identifying the Lord as the only truly righteous one echoes Old Testament monotheism. This sets God apart from creation, pointing readers to the unique holiness of the Creator.
verses.sectionHeader: The Wisdom and Mercy of God

verses.text: No one can fully declare his works. Who can search out his glorious deeds?
verses.comment: This verse highlights human limitation in understanding the fullness of God’s works. It echoes the humility required before the mystery of God.

verses.text: Who can measure his majestic power, and who can further tell of his mercies?
verses.comment: God’s mercy is linked to his majesty. The unmeasurable nature of God’s love forms the foundation of all redemption.

verses.text: It is not possible to lessen, or to add, nor is it possible to explore the wonders of the Lord.
verses.comment: Affirms the completeness and perfection of God’s works. This connects with Paul’s doxology in Romans about the inscrutability of God’s ways.

verses.text: When a man has finished, he is just beginning, and when he stops, he will be in need.
verses.comment: Human effort is always incomplete before God; only the Lord is self-sufficient. This encourages humility and ongoing reliance on God’s providence.

verses.text: What are human beings, and what use are they? What is good in them, and what is evil?
verses.comment: This echoes wisdom literature that ponders mankind’s frailty and moral ambiguity, preparing for the later Christian recognition of the need for grace.

verses.text: The number of a person's days is great if it reaches a hundred years.
verses.comment: Human life, even at its fullest, is portrayed as limited. This points to the transitory nature of earthly existence.

verses.text: Like a drop of water from the sea and a grain of sand, so are a few years in the day of eternity.
verses.comment: This vivid imagery emphasizes the vast difference between God’s eternity and our brief lives.

verses.text: Therefore the Lord is patient with mankind, and pours out his mercy upon them.
verses.comment: The Lord’s patience and mercy provide the foundation for salvation history, foreshadowing Christ’s redemptive mission.

verses.text: He sees and recognizes that their end is evil; therefore he multiplies forgiveness.
verses.comment: God’s knowledge moves him to mercy. This multiplication of forgiveness echoes Jesus’s teaching on boundless forgiveness.

verses.text: The mercy of a man is for his neighbor, but the mercy of the Lord is for all living things. He rebukes, disciplines, and teaches, and brings them back as a shepherd leads his flock.
verses.comment: This verse prefigures Christ, the Good Shepherd, who came for all. The Lord's universal mercy and his role as teacher and guide are essential themes for understanding salvation.

verses.text: He has compassion on those who accept discipline and who eagerly seek after his judgments.
verses.comment: God's mercy is especially abundant to those who repent and seek his will. The call to discipline and obedience suggests a life oriented toward virtue and God's commands.

verses.text: My child, do not add reproach to your good deeds, nor cause grief through harsh words given with a gift.
verses.comment: Generosity should be accompanied by kindness. Genuine charity avoids boasting or bitterness—a spiritual disposition essential to authentic giving.

verses.text: Does not the dew soothe the heat? So also a kind word is better than a gift.
verses.comment: A gentle, encouraging word can bring greater comfort than material gifts. The analogy underlines the power of speech to build up or heal.

verses.text: Certainly, the kind word is above the best gift. Every giving is accompanied by the gracious fear of the Lord.
verses.comment: Proper giving is completed in reverence for God. True virtue unites both deed and attitude.

verses.text: A fool may give grudgingly, but the wise person presents gifts with a cheerful face.
verses.comment: Joy and willingness in charity reflect a heart conformed to God's own love, as later echoed by Paul.

verses.text: Before you speak, learn; and before you become ill, take care of yourself.
verses.comment: Wisdom counsels prudence in word and action. Preparation and care are forms of discipline that foster virtue.

verses.text: Before judgment, examine yourself, and at the time of visitation you will find mercy.
verses.comment: Self-examination is key to repentance and personal holiness. This concept is vital to a sacramental view of confession, where introspection leads to mercy.

verses.text: Before falling ill, humble yourself; and when you sin, show repentance.
verses.comment: Humility and repentance before God’s discipline secure his mercy. Note the implication of an ongoing process of conversion throughout life.

verses.text: Do not delay to turn to the Lord, nor postpone conversion from day to day.
verses.comment: Immediate repentance is urged—today is the day of salvation. The urgency recalls Jesus’ call to be ever-prepared for God’s coming.

verses.text: Suddenly the wrath of the Lord will break forth, and in the time of punishment you will be destroyed.
verses.comment: There is a real danger in spiritual procrastination. Echoes Old Testament warnings of divine justice.

verses.text: Do not rely on riches, and say, 'I have enough,' and do not let them lead you astray down the wrong path.
verses.comment: Wealth can be a deception, tempting one away from God. Jesus later warns about the dangers of riches more strongly.

verses.text: Do not say, 'Who has power over me?'— for the Lord will surely punish you.
verses.comment: Pride before God is folly. All are accountable to His authority.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I have sinned, and nothing happened to me,' for the Lord is patient.
verses.comment: God’s patience is meant to lead to repentance, not presumption.

verses.text: Do not be so confident of forgiveness that you add sin upon sin.
verses.comment: Warning against presuming upon God’s mercy. True repentance avoids willful sin.

verses.text: Do not say, 'His compassion is great, he will forgive the multitude of my sins,' for both mercy and wrath are with him, and his anger rests on sinners.
verses.comment: This verse warns against presuming upon God’s mercy without sincere repentance, emphasizing that divine compassion is inseparable from justice; similar warnings appear in Romans 2:4-5 and Wisdom 11:21, reminding readers that God’s patience does not negate his righteous judgment.

verses.text: Do not delay to humble yourself before the Lord, and do not wait to do so until you are dying.
verses.comment: The necessity of dying prepared is an ancient Christian teaching. It evokes the wise and foolish virgins in Jesus’s parable—preparation is essential.

verses.text: Before making a vow, prepare your soul; do not be like one who tests the Lord.
verses.comment: Deliberation and sincerity are necessary before sacred promises, reminiscent of Jesus’ warnings against rash vows.

verses.text: Think about God’s wrath on the day of death, and at the time of retribution, when he will turn his face away.
verses.comment: Final judgment and afterlife are reinforced here, pointing to the need for an eternal perspective.

verses.text: In the time of plenty, remember the time of hunger; in the days of wealth, remember poverty and need.
verses.comment: Thinking ahead stirs gratefulness and caution. Practicing moderation is a mark of wisdom.

verses.text: From morning to evening conditions change; so all things pass swiftly before the Lord.
verses.comment: The transience of life is expressed, recalling the Psalms. This calls for constant faithfulness.

verses.text: A wise person is always careful in everything, and in days of sin will guard against offense.
verses.comment: Continuous vigilance is the mark of true wisdom. The life of virtue demands self-examination and prudence.
